physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I am very glad that you are giving me September. Please lead off with “Lead Soldiers,” as it is much the best poem you have got.

So far as I know, there is no truth in the rumour that I am to be poetry editor of “The New Republic.” Nobody has approached me on the subject, and so far as I know several of the editors of “The New Republic” are not particularly crazy about the new types of poetry; so I should think it very unlikely that they would smile upon my appointment. It is a job I should like extremely, but I cannot think it would come my way. Thank you for your good word with Francis Hackett. He is a queer creature, and I suspect that forgetting appointments is a habit with him, as I have known him to do it before. I quite agree with you in what you say about “The New Republic,” but we must not forget that the men in charge of it are chiefly interested in politics and, although they try to keep up the other side as well, they started t
he review to air their political views. They have asked me to write them an article on “The New Manner in Modern Poetry,” which of course I shall do; and they have accepted two poems of mine, but I have no idea when they are going to publish them.
We are still in Brookline, because my friend Mrs. Russell is not at all well. What are you going to do for the summer?
